qas.question: How much was China going to invest in the European Galileo positioning system project?
In 2003, what was the planned purpose of the BeiDou navigation system?

answers.text: only be used by its armed forces

qas.question: When did China join the Galileo project?
When was China Galileo Industries (CGI) founded?
Who said in 2008 that China was unsatisfied with its involvement in the Galileo project?

answers.text: the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post

qas.question: In January 2015, China was set to invest how much in Galileo over the following years?
How many million USD is equivalent to 160 million rupees?

plausible_answers.text: Agreement on the Cooperation in the Galileo Program

qas.question: Which agreement did Japan sign to join the Galileo project officially?

plausible_answers.text: Sino-European Cooperation Agreement on Galileo program

qas.question: Which program says CGI founded in 2008?
By April of 2006, how many cooperation projects between Japan and EU had been signed?

context: In September 2003, China intended to join the European Galileo positioning system project and was to invest <a0_0><b5_0>€230 million<b5_0/> (<b6_0>USD296 million<b6_0/>, GBP160 million)<a0_0/> in Galileo over the next few years. At the time, it was believed that China's "BeiDou" navigation system would then <a1_0>only be used by its armed forces<a1_0/>. In <a2_0>October 2004<a2_0/>, China officially joined the Galileo project by signing the <b7_0>Agreement on the Cooperation in the Galileo Program<b7_0/> between the "Galileo Joint Undertaking" (GJU) and the "National Remote Sensing Centre of China" (NRSCC). Based on the <b8_0>Sino-European Cooperation Agreement on Galileo program<b8_0/>, China Galileo Industries (CGI), the prime contractor of the China’s involvement in Galileo programs, was founded in <a3_0>December 2004<a3_0/>. By April 2006, <b9_0>eleven<b9_0/> cooperation projects within the Galileo framework had been signed between China and EU. However, <a4_0>the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post<a4_0/> reported in January 2008 that China was unsatisfied with its role in the Galileo project and was to compete with Galileo in the Asian market.
